Renowned San Francisco photographer Ansel Adams' secluded chalet in the ritzy Sea Cliff neighborhood recently went on sale for $5 million.

Originally built in 1902 as an Arts and Crafts chalet-style home on the remote dunes of what was then known as the city's outside lands, the expanded home sits on the edge of the Presidio.

Adams, a renowned photographer and environmentalist, redesigned the space with his wife in 1929, adding a "grand salon annex" to the original home structure, Sotheby's International Realty said in a press release.

"The merged home became the residential seat of America's most lauded landscape photographer until 1957, when he moved his family to the Monterey Peninsula," the property listing states.

Sotheby's representatives say that Adams' home was a core meeting place for San Francisco's arts community, where guests would frequently bring music and operatic songs to the home's residential salon.
Other perks in the Presidio home include an attic-turned-artist's loft, views of the Golden Gate Bridge and a terraced garden design.

The estate is listed by Sotheby's for $5.45 million and sits along West Clay Park. It features three bedrooms and two baths. Joseph Lucier and Stacey Caen represent the house for Sotheby's.

ð¸: David Duncan Livingston for Sothebyâs International Realty

Japan's iconic Nozomi Shinkansen bullet train has announced a change in its ticketing policy, affecting budget travelers during peak travel seasons. The railway company has decided to abolish the availability of low-priced unreserved tickets for these busy periods. The decision aims to enhance passenger comfort and efficiency by ensuring a smoother boarding process and reducing overcrowding on the famous train route.

With the removal of low-priced unreserved tickets during peak travel seasons, passengers planning to experience the Nozomi Shinkansen should consider booking their tickets in advance. By securing reserved seats, you'll ensure a stress-free and comfortable journey, enjoying the renowned speed and punctuality of Japan's high-speed rail network.

Share your thoughts on this ticketing change in the comments below! Have you traveled on the Nozomi Shinkansen before?

#News #NozomiShinkansen #BulletTrain #JapanTravel #RailwayNews #TravelTips #HighSpeedRail"

Coffee Shop Neon Tour of California

Today on Zoom! 9:30 am PDT
With Stephen Coles and Randall Ann Homan. Register at neonspeaks.org or link in bio.

Wake up and see the coffee. Join Stephen Coles (Letterform Archive) and Randall Ann Homan (SF Neon) on a neon tour of coffee and coffee shop typography in the Golden State. With their adventurous architecture, and sensational signs to match, coffee shops became the most popular eateries in the early days of great American road trip era. If you love typography, coffee, and neon, then join us for a virtual tour of California coffee shops. Some are still pouring a strong cup, some have faded into highway mirages. Includes a short history of coffee shops and a look at new neon coffee signs, it's a thing! (Photo and coffee cup sign from the collection of David Webb, @onemanswapmeet). #neonspeaks2023 #signsunited #signhunters

The Many Ghosts of L.A.

Yesterday was the 5th anniversary of this account, and I canât think of a better way to commemorate the occasion than with a collection of silhouettes of people wandering in and out of a photographerâs shot while their shutterâs open, stepping into the wet cement of moments freezing in time. Each of these has been cropped from a larger photo, some of which Iâve shared before and a few that are still to come. 

When I started this thing, back in 2018, it was just meant to be an outlet where I could offload some research that Iâd done for a 1940s film project that was put on hold, and my bio at the time just said âa screenwriterâs scratchpad about L.A.â Since then, your constant enthusiasm and endless support has fueled my quest to learn everything I can about this city, and I have found myself diving down some pretty obscure rabbit holes, and digging up some pretty wild, unique, and, at times, utterly shocking stories that I will never forget. And you guys are always here, happy to come along for the ride, bringing further insights in your comments and messages, sharing memories and filling in the blanks, and I get to learn so much more.

Thank you, thank you, thank you for traveling with me through time. 

â

Your Ghost Guide:

â¢ 1. Taken at the Vogue Theatre & Market by G. Haven Bishop, April 1938.

â¢ 2. Ninth & Broadway, Christmas 1931 

â¢ 3-4. Spectators observe a lunar eclipse at the Griffith Observatory, April 12, 1949

â¢ 5. Vaudeville spectators at the Empress Theatre, taken by G. Haven Bishop in 1913

â¢ 6. Looking east on 7th from Grand, December 4, 1941.

â¢ 7-8. Hot rod racing in the LA River, photographed by Allan Grant for LIFE in March of 1957.

â¢ 9. Early 1930s photo taken for SoCal Edison to document the lighting. No further info. 

â¢ 10. Posted this a few weeks ago. Angels Flight in 1951.

â

Photos: 1,5,9 via @thehuntingtonlibrary , 2,6,10 via USC, 3-4 via @uclalibrary , 7-8 from LIFE Magazine.

Also, on that note, thank you to the various librarians and archivists who make an account like this even possible, and to the many historians who have come before me, whose work Iâm often borrowing from or building upon.

I know the storm is over, but Iâm still looking back at these wild shots of a water-logged LA, coming off a full day of heavy rains on January 17, 1952.

According to papers, we had 3.39 inches of rain fall over the city in a matter of hours, causing four deaths, hundreds of evacuations, and millions of dollars of damage.

â

Photos: 

â¢ 1. Taken at Sunset Plaza, which was completely washed out and caked in mud after the storm.

â¢ 2. Looking down Lucerne Blvd. from 3rd Street, just south of Larchmont Village. 

â¢ 3. Pretty cool shot taken inside the photographer's car, looking down the 2300 block of Benedict Canyon Drive in Beverly Hills.

â¢ 4. Taken at 542 S. Broadway, where a fire hydrant burst during the storm.

â¢ 5. Taken in Pasadena, where a billboard directs motorists toward the Santa Anita Hastings tract office located one block away. Address was 375 Cliff Drive.

â¢ 6. The Cork and Bottle liquor store in Venice, located at 712 Lincoln Boulevard. An unlit sign on the far left offers Free Parking for the Fox Theatre... "while attending."

â¢ 7. A bus approaches the corner of 2nd and Figueroa.

â¢ 8. Roth's Market, once located at 8240 Firestone Blvd. in Downey, where manager Dean Lambert stands in the middle of his flooded store. Love that Van de Kamp's Bakery neon in the upper right. 

â¢ 9. Location unknown, possibly Artesia. 

â¢ 10. Sherman Way in Reseda, where a towing crew works to retrieve a car that veered off the bridge at night.

___

All photos via the Los Angeles Examiner Collection at USC

I spent some time before my DJ gig tonight at the house of Josh Curtis, brother of the promoter, Cahn Curtis.  Josh is like a brother from another mother! 
OK, before I startâ¦ Let me tell all you creeps: none of this stuff is for sale!  This is a carefully curated collection he has worked on for decades.  So keep that in mind when youâre reading this postâ¦ Nothing is for sale! 
He gave me the tour of his ranch, strewn about with old cars, World War II, jeeps, old barns, and all sorts of amazing things to look at.  One of the cars is a 1929 Chevrolet that was stolen by Clyde Barrow and used for three Iowa robberies by Bonnie and Clyde, before they abandoned it for another stolen vehicle. 
In the back of the lot, a De Soto Suburban stretch wagon from the 1940s caught my eye.  These suckers are rare, and I was interested because Merle Travis used to tour in one of these with his band in the late 40s. Could this be Merle Travisâ old tour vehicle? Maybe it wound up out here in the Inland Empire?
Then Josh took the inside his 1915 Sears and Roebuck kit home, which is preserved in a remarkable state of originality.  At that point, he started pulling out some real mind blowing stuff from his collection.
Josh has collected all kinds of stuff and Iâm sure I could have stayed there for a few days while he pulled stuff out. But we started with vintage clothing, and he has a crazy collectionâ¦wow!
I saw Mickey Cohenâs robe,  Elvis Presleyâs army shirt, a Gene Autry suit, a Bob Hope jacket, a Frank Sinatra jacket, a Spike Jones jacket, Tommy Dorsey shirt, a Johnny Cash shirtâ¦ a suit owned by Clyde Barrow of Bonnie and Clyde, and one of Buddy Hollyâs shirts! Too much amazing stuff!
Before long, I had to get to my gig.  Before I left, however, Josh gifted me a hubcap and a piece of the exhaust from a car he had bought and sold a few years ago: a Cadillac that Johnny Cash bought for June Carter in 1965. When he decided to sell the vehicle, He kept a hubcap and this piece of the exhaustâ¦ And gave it to me! Does this mean I have to start my own âOne Piece at a Timeâ psychobilly Cadillac? 
Thanks for the tour, Josh, my mind was blown!

In 2002, the photographer Michael Jang dropped off a box of prints at San Franciscoâs Museum of Modern Art. He had taken the pictures in the 1970s, and hadnât looked at them much since then. Only now, as his teenage children were in school and he was winding down his successful career as a family and editorial portrait photographer, had he begun to delve into the archive of negatives, contact prints and enlargements stored in his garage. At the time, the museum had a policy that any portfolio submitted by any artist would be reviewed by its curators. Jang wondered if they might be interested.

Many of the photos were taken in the early 1970s, while Jang â a shy Chinese-American boy from Marysville, a suburban town in northern California â was studying at CalArts in Los Angeles. Majoring as a design student, on a whim Jang had taken an elective course in photography, a choice that turned out to be life-defining.

A famed route on the smallest of Japanâs four main islands offers breathtaking views and an array of lessons on history, culture and generosity.

The pilgrimage on Shikoku is a 750-mile route that links 88 Buddhist temples, each of which claims a connection to Kukai, a celebrated monk â posthumously known as Kobo Daishi â who, after returning from a trip to China in the ninth century, founded one of the major schools of Buddhism in Japan.

After Kukaiâs death in 835, wanderers began making pilgrimages to the sites on Shikoku that were affiliated with his life and work: his birth and burial places, the caves where he meditated, the sites of various religious rites. Later, these sites were linked, and the temples and shrines were formally numbered.

As is true with many modern-day pilgrimages, the ranks of Shikoku pilgrims â once exclusively practitioners of Shingon Buddhism, one of the major schools of Buddhism in Japan â have grown to include travelers with a more diverse array of motivations. And so the steady succession of monks, priests and faithful Buddhists has given way to young people on journeys of self-discovery, older hikers enjoying their retirement and even foreign visitors who know little of the language and customs but are drawn by the adventure of the trek.

Tap the link in our bio to read more from @nytimestravel about the Shikoku Pilgrimage and advice for how to embark on the journey yourself. Photos by @martagiaccone

Jesse McReynolds has passed away at the age of 92.

McReynolds was born in 1929 in Coeburn, Virginia. His grandfather, Charles, led a group called The Bull Mountain Moonshiners, who made their initial recordings at the 1927 Bristol Sessions. 

Around 1947, Jesse started performing with his brother Jim as The McReynolds Brothers. In 1952, the brothers began recording for Capitol Records under the name Jim and Jesse. The brothers recorded and performed together until Jimâs death in 2002.

Jesse continued to perform as a solo artist after his brotherâs passing including making appearances as a member of the Grand Ole Opry. In 2019, he celebrated 55 years of Opry membership. 

Here is a video of Jim and Jesse performing âParadiseâ in 1976.

Gene Wilder had to fight to have this singing moment included in the 1974 comedy horror âYoung Frankensteinâ.

Itâs an unexpected pattern that weâve found in our reading - creative battles over whether a musical moment works in a non-musical film.

For this film Gene Wilder and Mel Brooks set out to create a parody of the classic black-and-white film adaptations of Mary Shelleyâs novel âFrankensteinâ by director James Whale. Brooks felt this singing moment was ridiculous, but Gene thought it critical for Dr Frankenstein to be able to demonstrate how amazing the monster really was.

Brooks later said: 

âGene was dead right because it took the movie to another levelâour level. Thatâs what audiences were paying for. They werenât paying for a true artistic resemblance to James Whaleâs movies. They wanted to laugh.â

Gene understood an audienceâs love of surprise donât you think?

Calling all Angelenos! We have some BIG news that weâre super excited about: next month we will be hosting a pop-up experience all about LAâs gourmet past, present, and future at Grand Central Market! This is such a big step for LAExplained as weâre so proud of this city and weâre looking to showcase its culinary history â but we need your help!

We have so many fun things and collaborations that weâll be announcing in the coming weeks but want to make this space not just about us â but about you. Weâre on the lookout for vintage menus, postcards, matchbooks, signage, dining booths, displays, and more! On a more personal level â weâre looking for Angelenosâ family recipes, anecdotes, event invitations, personal photos of vintage LA dining experiences, anything and everything food-related that you can think of.Â

The Legend of Hiney Wine
January 3, 20165  Bryan Dent

Written by Bryan Dent
As hoaxes go, so-called Hiney Wine â advertised on radio stations all across America in the early 1980s â wasnât too hard to see through. Nevertheless, enough people got taken in that the gag took on a life of its own, even spawning a real-life Hiney Wine that still stalks the land to this day.
Hiney Wine was the brainchild of a radio DJ named Terry Dorsey, who in 1981 was the morning guy at struggling station KPLX in Dallas. Dorsey scripted a bogus commercial for a place called âHiney Wineryâ and aired it for laughs. The winery was supposedly founded by Uncle Harry Hiney, a homebrewer who was persuaded by his nephews Big Red Hiney and Thor Hiney (get it?) that âhis Hiney was too good to keep to himself.â No butt-joke or bad pun was too lame to run: the entire Hiney clan formed a âcrack inspection teamâ to ensure no Hiney Wine was sold before its time, and the Hiney Winery motto was, âyou only go around once in life, so grab all the Hiney you can get.â
The Hiney spots proved to be such a hit â and fooled enough listeners â that Dorsey and the general manager at the station, T. J. Donnelly, sold the scripts to radio stations around the country (Los Angeles DJ Rick Dees, of âDisco Duckâ fame, ran them for years). The ads were altered to give a different location for Hiney Winery depending on where they aired. Listeners in Virginia (for example) were told Hiney was headquartered on Butts Station Road in Chesapeake, Virginia; Vermonters were told it came from the small town of Hinesburg, Vermont. The location given was usually a real place, and residents of these obscure locales found themselves fending off visitors asking, innocently or not, where they could find Hiney.
Dorsey and Donnelly made even more money by selling Hiney paraphernalia: buttons, ballcaps, t-shirts and the like. They kept the hoax alive as long as possible, changing locations around and telling callers who complained they couldnât find Hiney that the winery had burned down, but would be re-opening again shortly.
Eventually the gag ran its course â some would say none too soon. See article in bio for rest of article.

Photos by Louis Faurer 

Photo 1: Chelsea Hotel, New York, 1971

Photo 2: Twins, New York, 1948

Photo 3: Market Street, Philadelphia, 1937

Photo 8: Freudian Woman, New York, 1947 

Born in Philadelphia in 1916 to Polish immigrant parents, Louis Faurer bought his first camera, a 35mm Kodak Vollenda, at age 21. After studying drawing and submitting work to Disney Studios while still an adolescent (he was considered for an in-house position), he enrolled in a commercial lettering school. Thereafter, he created advertising posters, worked at several Philadelphia portrait studios and sketched caricatures in Atlantic City. In 1947, he left for New York, where he became a photographer for Junior Bazaar. He soon met Robert Frank through the publication, and the two became friends and shared Mr. Frank's studio. He continued to photograph until 1984, when after being struck by a car, before he died in 2001. 

With his blurred backdrops and tenderness towards his human subjects, Faurer was one of the United Statesâ most unashamedly poetic photographers. 

âMy eyes search for people who are grateful for life, people who forgive and whose doubts have been removed, who understand the truth, whose enduring spirit is bathed by such piercing white light as to provide their present and future hope.â - Louis Faurer

Some are happy to be carpenters, some are happy to be farmers and some are happy to be chefs. For decades, Haseyan has been happy to be a carpenter, a farmer and a chef all in one.

In 1982, Haseyan started "Canadian farm" in Hara village. He was 26 years old. For more than forty years, the man has built an organic farm, a restaurant, a gallery, a shop, a guesthouse, almost a village. All with his own hands, with his sense of creativity and with many reclaimed materials from his forest and land. Many of his buildings are unique in their form and structure. "No form, no meaning" says Haseyan.

At almost 70, Haseyan gets up at 5 am every day, goes to work on one of his construction sites, then goes to his farm to pick herbs, plant vegetables before opening the restaurant, preparing and serving meals with his employees. The restaurant offers dishes cooked on wood fires, with products from the farm, smoked meat, dried by Haseyan, bread made by Kumi-san at the restaurant and known for its quality.

Haseyan showed us his examples of makistove cookers, designed to heat water, the ground, the air (because of a system of pipes under the fireplace), but also imagined to make bread, takoyaki or okonomiyakis, to cook fish or to steam.

He had created it with his own hands, like everything else, like all the huge buildings, like the benches and the children's games. Haseyan is also a child. He likes to play with shapes, to create. In his forest we found a building with a door handle made from one of his many chainsaws.

Haseyan is an artist, a free spirit in his way of life as much as in his creations. 

We spent a week at the Canadian farm during the golden week to help out. Every day is a good day because, whether it's on the farm, on the job site or in the restaurant, Haseyan is happy to do what he does, and to share it with those who are interested. For us, Haseyan is more than just an interest. He is a very good friend and a real source of inspiration.

On this date in 1978, Talking Heads landed on the Billboard Hot 100 chart for or the first time with their debut single, "Psycho Killer". The song would peak at #92 (March 11th 1978).

The video here is the classic PSYCHO KILLER, as performed on The Old Grey Whistle Test, the embodiment of David Byrne's contradictory rock: a throbbing expanse of vehemence - a song about communication and disgust at having to listen to people constantly repeat themselves then retaliating by being terse and leaving.

'I can't seem to face up to the facts / I'm tense and nervous and I can't relax / I can't sleep cause my bed's on fire / Don't touch me, I'm a real live wire / Psycho killer...'

Byrne wrote the song in 1973 at the Rhode Island School of Design (RISD), where he and drummer Chris Frantz had a band called The Artistics. When Byrne presented the song, he explained that he wanted a Japanese section in the bridge, but when he asked a girl who spoke the language to come up with some murderous words, she understandably freaked out. 

Frantz' girlfriend, Tina Weymouth, spoke French, so they had her write a French part for the bridge instead. She drew inspiration from the Norman Bates character in the 1960 Alfred Hitchcock thriller Psycho, which influenced the next verse:

You start a conversation you can't even finish it
You're talking a lot, but you're not saying anything
When I have nothing to say, my lips are sealed
Say something once, why say it again?

Byrne incorporated a French line into the chorus: "Qu'est-ce que c'est?" (meaning "What is this?") and followed it with a stuttering warning:

Fa-fa-fa-fa-fa-fa-fa-fa-fa-far better
Run, run, run, run, run, run, run away

The end result is one of the most famous songs about a psychopathic murderer, influenced by two touchstones of the genre: Alice Cooper and the movie Psycho.

The French section in the Bridge roughly translates to:

What I did that night
What she said that night
Realizing my hopes
I launch myself towards a glorious destiny

This reveals that the psycho killer is targeting a woman, just as Norman Bates did in Psycho.

David Byrne and Chris Frantz played this a few times in 1974 with their band The Artistics.

Rock legend Neil Young made a surprise appearance Saturday at an old-growth logging protest rally. â 
â 
He said he came out for the trees. â 
â 
âYou know Iâm only here for those trees up there â¦ I hope our Canadian government and business section will recognize that this has to do with Canada,â he said, accompanied by his wife, actress Daryl Hannah.â 
â 
Young wasnât listed to appear at the event, which was held outside the British Columbia legislature, but after making his remarks, he ended up singing two songs: Comes A Time, which has a chorus about tall trees, and classic hit Heart of Gold.â 
â 
Earlier this month, the B.C. government introduced new plans to protect more old-growth trees from logging.â 
â 
Premier David Eby said more areas are now being deferred from logging than ever on record.â 
â 
The old-growth deferral is a government program where old-growth areas slated for logging are deferred until a later date or not logged at all.â 
â 
Eby says the logging deferral of old-growth forests is now at 2.1 million hectares, up from last springâs report of 1.7 million hectares.â 
â

In early December, somewhere on a mountain on the Japanese island of Shikoku, thereâs a citrus tree laden with golden-yellow fruit, each one no larger than a kumquat. There arenât many of them in the wild. â 
â 
Scratch the peel on one of those tiny fruits, and youâll release a remarkably powerful fragrance, full of zesty, spicy, bitter notes, a dozen citruses distilled into a single whiff. â 
â 
Its flesh is an electric burst of tart and bitter flavors, far more intense than a lemon or grapefruit, followed by a barely detectable undertone of sweetness.â 
â 
This delicate little citrus is the tachibana. It is one of only two citruses native to Japanâthe other being the Okinawan shequasarâand is extremely rare. â 
â

Lux Interior in a striped suit during a Cramps gig on April 1st, 1978, for the re-opening of the short-lived CBGB 2nd Avenue Theatre, an event which obviously called for a formal attire, as captured by Pat Hefley (thereâs another iconic shot from that gig by Stephanie Chernikowski on the back cover of âGravest Hitsâ, with #luxinterior climbing over the chairs mid-audience).

#cbgb2ndavenuetheater , was #hillykristal âs brilliant, yet poorly executed plan to expand with an additional show venue of a near-2,000-capacity which could host the crowds that were getting out of hand at #CBGB OMFUG. Unfortunately he never really checked out how shabby the building really was.
According to various anecdotes from Roman Kozak's âThis Ain't No Disco: The Story of CBGBâ(1988):
â...It opened on a Tuesday night, Dec. 27, '77, with Talking Heads headlining, supported by the Shirts & the Tuff Darts. The next night it was the Dictators & the Dead Boys. Patti Smith headlined December 29, 30 & 31. There were problems right from the beginning...
...[says] Bill Shumaker. "It was in December, it was bitter cold, but the heating system never really worked. I never went down into the basement, but you could look down & it honestly looked like one of the rings in Dante's Inferno. And down there was the boiler. Everybody got serious colds...
[Sound engineer] Norman Dunn: "It was an exercise in how many things could go wrong. The boiler room was under eleven feet of water because the water mains broke. The generator outside was running the electricity for everything & it was driving the neighbors crazy...There were threats, the police were there;...
Joel Webber is even more graphic: "The place was disgusting. We were talking about 80 years' worth of dirt. I mean there was popcorn left over from the last performance of the Yiddish theater in 1925...â.After the Patti Smith dates, the Theater closed, briefly used as a rock'nâroll flea market, re-opening for shows with the Jam & the Tuff Darts on March 31st & #thecramps , the Erasers & the Sic F*cks on April 1st 1978. It is believed that by nid-â78 the new enterprise had come to an end, costing Kristal a loss of about $160,000.

share.share_text: I love going to estate sales. Most of you know that about me. Iâll be honest with you, buying more âstuffâ hasnât been my goal for a very long time. Yes, occasionally Iâll buy a book, or a record, or some tools. The thing that truly piques my interest, however, is getting a glimpse into the past, behind closed doors that never would have been open otherwise.  Like walking through archaeological ruins, estate sales fascinate me. I see homes where people used to live and who obviously once cared a lot about their spaces.  Fancy serving plates. Sculpted back yard gardens. Garage workbenches. Sewing rooms. Through sickness, death, apathy, or any multitude of reasons, these places become neglected and eventually fall prey to the careless hands of the throngs of estate sale diggers and pickers.  This thought is never far from my mind when Iâm carefully cultivating the style of my house, arranging collectors items that mean a lot to me, or simply keeping a home filled with love and laughter and joie de vivre.  I know some day these same careless pickers will be digging through my stuff, making a huge mess, and eradicating the lovely place that I called home.  Iâm not sure why Iâm so fascinated watching this process happen to dead peopleâs homes, but like a train wreck, I canât seem to look away. And of course, every now and then I will dig some impossibly rare treasure out of a pile of forgotten rubble, and I feel like maybe I have saved and preserved one tiny part of that personâs legacy.  One thing is for sure, though, no matter how much âstuffâ you accumulate, your time on this planet isnât very long, and itâs over before you know it.

Did you know when Joel Russ, the founder of Russ & Daughters first came to the USA as an immigrant from Poland, that he started his âappetizingâ business from a pushcart before opening his iconic shop on East Houston Street. And exactly 84 years ago today on December 1, 1938 NYC Mayor Fiorella LaGuardia in an effort to âclean up the streetsâ outlawed pushcarts and forced many immigrant peddlers to stop selling merchandise on the street and use their life savings to relocate their business indoors to a market (the Essex Street Market in the Lower East Side also opened on December 1, 1938). Immigrant peddlers who could not afford an indoor stand were simply out of luck. 
Thankfully Joel Russ had the foresight to save his money and open his family-owned business @russanddaughters in 1914. The store is believed to be the first shop to have ever used the words â& Daughtersâ in its official name as businesses were usually passed from father to son. It is now co-owned by @nikirussfederman the great granddaughter of its founder. Russ & Daughters Appetizers also has one of our favorite #neon signs in all of NYC as it not only has gorgeous channel letters in two different colors but the storeâs name is also flanked by two neon whitefish in a downward dog pose. Although the shop itself dates back to 1914, the #neonsign was installed in 1951 and was refurbished by @lettherebeneon in 2008. We absolutely love the signage and have also photographed it at night (swipe left for 2nd photo)
â¢
Our photo of Russ & Daughters is one of the many #momandpopshop of New York City which we will have on display at Village Works Gallery & Bookstore located at 90 East 3rd Street between 1st & 2nd Avenues. Fukaya. Saitama prefecture.

In Fukaya, it is possible to discover a rare site: a cinema in a old sake factory.

Several decades ago, Takeishi, originally from Tokyo, moved to Fukaya, his wife's hometown. Passionate about cinema, the man discovered an old abandoned sake factory. There, a great project was born: to revive the place, by multiplying the activities there, the most important of which would be the opening of a real cinema. For this, Takeishi had to renovate the place. Optimistic and determined, he created an association and collected all the funds. The cinema was born in 2002.

The cinema building has retained its original charm.  Inside, visitors can discover a different programme from other cinemas, with many films rares, engaged, documentaries,  from many countries of the world but also classics. People can give their opinion about the movies to project. Takeishi also bought two old projectors and almost two hundred old reel-to-reel films in Tokyo. From time to time, the cinema offers the screening of an old film, a treasure to be preserved for the manager.

Inside the old sake factory, there are several valuable buildings. They are also rented out. Several activities accompany the cinema, such as a cafÃ©, a 2nd hand bookstore, local craft shops, and a hall hosts events such as dance performances and workshops.
On the occasion of the twentieth anniversary of the cinema, the association is planning to buy the whole site to ensure its preservation. The site is threatened by a road project.
Because of its architectural character, charm, history and special features, the cinema regularly receives financial support from individuals and even actors and directors. Several years ago, the actress Kirin Kiki came to Fukaya and made a large donation, attracted by the project.

Through its action, the association wishes to revitalise a town affected by numerous abandoned houses and buildings.

Do not hesitate to contact the cinema if you wish to support the project.

What happens in a nature documentary when there is no David Attenborough, no Morgan Freeman or Sigourney Weaver, lending voice-over and theatrical narration? What happens when viewers are left to piece together an animalâs story on their own? This is the challenge that the filmmakers @jack_weisman and Gabriela Osio Vanden (@sanguinuss) set for themselves in âNuisance Bear,â a short documentary that they shot in the town of Churchill, Manitoba, where travellers arrive in droves every autumn to see polar bears migrating as sea ice begins to form on the Hudson Bay. The footage in âNuisance Bearâ reveals as much about the behavior of the humans as that of the bears. Each fall, Japanese maple trees fade from green to golden-yellowâa phenomenon that inspires those who witness it. Some write poetry. Others make art. â 
â 
In Minoh City, locals rip the young foliage off trees, age it in salt for a year, and then fry each leaf for 20 minutes.â 
â 
What does a year-old, salted maple leaf taste like? Nothing much, apparently. â 
â 
Instead, merchants use the leaf as an attractive frame for the sweet coating, which is drier and crispier than the tempura surrounding, say, a shrimp. Some cooks also add sesame seeds for an extra pop of flavor. â 
â 
Locals refer to maples as momiji, which means âbecomes crimson-leaved.â The word also translates literally to âbabyâs hands,â but fret notâno babies were harmed in the making of this unusual treat. â 
â 
Baby maple leaves, on the other hand, are not so lucky. â

La Bodeguita del Medio is a typical restaurant-bar of Havana (Cuba). It is a famous tourist destination because of the personalities which have patronized it: Salvador Allende, the poet Pablo Neruda, the artist Josignacio and many others. La Bodeguita lays claim to being the birthplace of the Mojito cocktail, prepared in the bar since its opening in 1942, although this is disputed. Empire Diner is located inside a 1946 Fodero Dining Car on Tenth Avenue at w22nd Street in Chelsea. After surviving a few different ownerships as well as some extended closures over the years, the Empire Diner has been run by executive chef Jestin Feggan of Cafeteria and its managing partner Stacy Pisone since April 2017. We miss that this Art Deco diner no longer has the miniature stainless steel Empire State Building replica on its roof (which was removed in 2009) as seen in this photo which appears in our book "New York Nights". @empire_diner has been frequented by many artists and celebrities over the years including Bruce Springsteen who used to meet his then girlfriend Patti Scialfa on a bench next to the diner and proposed to her there. Empire Diner also has appeared in many movies including âMen in Blackâ & âHome Aloneâ and in numerous TV shows including Law And Order & Saturday Night Live.

Mind blown! I saw an odd thing on the âRoadsideAmericaâ app, about a neon business in Minneapolis that had a collection of vintage sputnik neon signs.  I wondered around a large industrial building until I saw a nondescript black door with a tiny sign that said âskyline neon.â I knocked on the door, and a woman named Annie let me in. She was working on restoring a vintage neon sign, which I found totally fascinating, and she also turned on all the working neon in the place so I could take some pictures. Her partner, the owner of the place, Matt, wasnât around, but I applaud Matt and Annie for being hospitable to strangers knocking on their doors! This place is incredible! All the old ones you see are part of Mattâs collection, but they do restoration of old signs and even build new neon signs that look like old ones. What an amazing place!

In the heart of downtown Kyoto, mere steps from the old Imperial Palace, a narrow stone-paved alley runs through a pocket of historic homes. Only the occasional passerby from the subway station reminds us that this is in fact modern Kyoto, not the ancient capital of centuries past. It was in this space that Junko Uchiyama and Christopher Flechtner found their home. The couple, along with their eight-year-old son, Nikki, sought a place that could serve as a family dwelling as well as a creative base for their firm, @christopherflechtner, which operates under Chrisâs name. The couple are prolific creators, designing innovative pieces from cargo bicycles to futuristic espresso machines, along with furniture and lighting for their new collaborative, @the_craftsmancollective. They looked at many properties, âbut nothing had any soul,â says Chris. âNothing felt inspiring.â Eventually, they set their sights on a 107-year-old machiya, a classic Kyoto townhouse. The intricacies of buying a home in Japan meant that a full inspection wasnât possible until after the deal was signedâand a closer look revealed several surprises. Along with a hauntingly large arachnid dried up in the sinkâwhich inspired the homeâs name, âSpider Hollowââthe homeâs wooden frame was a bit off kilter. Undeterred, Junko and Chris embarked on a renovation that embraced the homeâs quirks and put a playful spin on the classic style. And, in the process, they uncovered the perfect home for their family. Step inside our cover story at the link in our bio, or pick up the newest issue of Dwell Magazine.

Pasadena's "Circle Cafe" in 1946, looking like the kind of joint you'd see in a film noir where a decent kid could stop in with a wallet full of cash and wind up leaving with a bucket of problems. 

Located at 953 East Colorado, the Circle Cafe seems to have opened at some point in 1943, as their liquor license was granted that October, but the cafe didn't really make headlines until 1945 when the owners decided to paint the place fuchsia, upsetting local residents and business owners so much that they started leaning on the city to shut the place down. 

Within weeks, the city sent building inspectors who determined that the cafe's newly-pinkish walls protruded three inches over the sidewalk and thus needed to be stripped out. Circle Cafe's lawyers asked that the city simply "wink at it" until their lease was up, but given that they still had five years on it, the city took the request as a slap in the face and ordered them to face a "police court jury trial." Two months later, Circle was looking to settle, having already removed the controversial color from its facade, and promising to move its back its metal walls. As this shot was taken that November, this exterior was likely the compromise. 

After that, things seemed to settle for the cafe, and they ran for at least another decade without issue, but they do pop up in another preposterous legal battle in 1956, when they went up against an archaic Federal tax law which stated that if anybody ever sings in a bar, customers included, then the establishment will automatically owe a 20% "cabaret tax" for âproviding entertainment.â So if your friends drunkenly belt out an off-key verse of "Happy Birthday,â then the place is immediately deemed an entertainment venue, as "singing is singing,â "whether itâs being performed by professional entertainers or volunteer amateurs." 

The Tavern Owners Association of California had Circleâs back on that one and succeeded in overturning the law.

Finally, just want to point out that the âHot Menâ sign on the far right actually reads âHotel Mentorâ

â

Photo by J. Allen Hawkins, archived with the Pasadena Digital History Collection via Pasadena City College.

What a trip to see this in print. Thanks to everyone who sent in photos (obviously, I donât have a copy in hand). The Kii piece appeared in the May 3rd edition of The New York Times (A14). This was my first time having photos + essay in the print edition of a national / semi-global paper. 

I was all like: Ohh, no big deal, whatever, itâll be in print, blah blah blah. But âÂ you know what. ITâS KINDA COOL. Turns out: A lot of people read this thing in print. 

Feeling grateful for the attention. 

Huge thanks for all the kind emails and messages. Especially hearted by letters from folks writing *from* Kii â and from folks who grew up on the peninsula, now living elsewhere â with kind things to say, and stories of their own to share. Just hoping Iâve done justice as interloper to their amazing hunk of land given limited space. 

As Iâve said in newsletters, the book Iâm currently working on is Kii focused, with a strong memoir element. I hope for that project to also elevate and shine a unique light on the peninsula. 

Also also: Iâve sold a crazy number of copies of âKissa by Kissaâ in the last week, along with a bunch of SPECIAL PROJECTS memberships. So THANK YOU to everyone who felt inspired enough to buy a weird, expensive book about pizza toast (only ~200 copies left), and to become a member of an amorphous membership program with fuzzy deliverables. â¤ï¸â¤ï¸

These popular life-size food models are known as shokuhin sampuru. They are displayed outside countless casual Japanese restaurants, where they function as promotional materials and a way to boost sales. 

But the craftsmanship of a food model can be extraordinary â a fish so ridiculously crammed full of detail, so obsessively recreated, that you want the replica itself. No two fish look exactly the same at Ganso Shokuhin Sample-ya, a top-of-the-line shop in Tokyo operated by Iwasaki-Be-I, which displays the kinds of pieces the company makes for restaurants but also carries trinkets for tourists: cut bananas at varying stages of ripeness, bowls of pork cutlets on rice, sushi pieces and grilled fish. Some are better than others. Thatâs because each sample is made by hand â the work of 68 artisans across the companyâs six factories.

The photographer @kyokopajama, who was born in Tokyo and now lives in the United States, documented a wealth of modern samples on Kappabashi Dogugai Street, also called Kitchen Town. The Tokyo street is packed with kitchen stores, where competing shops carry sampuru made all over the country

This Muriel Spark book was missing the last page of text, left unintentionally blank. We found the ending online and filled it in. Emma did it because their handwriting is better than mine. This is NOT the first time Iâve found this book with a blank last page, which means at some point the publisher saw it and went âGood enough, the readers can figure out the ending on their own- SHIP IT!â. Overall, really enjoyed this book! another fantastic comedy of manners from the always delightful Spark, who towards the end of her life was still funny and weird and churning out biting, obscure references that make 150 page books whiz by in minutes and have you immediately reaching for another. Great to finally know how it all ends!

This is a very special post: to celebrate 10k followers, here's the video I've been most wanting to post since 2021 - a full dance tutorial by David Byrne!
I've spent so long searching/researching for this, but it gives me great pleasure to finally share it, it's genuinely a very fun dance routine to follow!

The video was recorded about a year ago, for SOCIAL!, a social distance dance club which David Byrne co-created during lockdown last year while away from American Utopia. It's quite a fascinating event that took place last April - anybody could sign up and attend an hour session of dancing, safely distanced from each other. For the final song, everybody was encouraged to dance in sync with the routine that you see in this video, provided in advance for attendees to learn.

NOTE: this is not to be confused with the similar video recorded in the same room+outfit, featured in the "Food for Love" charity stream in February 2021. I was searching for that video before I found out about this one, although the best I could previously find was the 2 low quality minute-long clips posted by the TikTok user called byrnetok.

Now that I've got info out of the way, time for some words about reaching 10k followers - wow! Never Thought this account would get so big. It's been quite time consuming, but very fun. I've loved interacting with all of you and seeing the enjoyment people have gotten from the daily clips of David in their feed. Now some thank yous:
To @dailydavidbyrnenoises - without his account, I wouldn't have had the idea to make mine!
To @csakjutka who helped me in my quest to find this
To everybody who's followed, interacted with, or sent suggestions to me
And to David Byrne for being such an inspiration, as a dancer/musician/artist/person!

The incredibly appropriately named Shari Elf was not even thinking of her crochet obsession when she purchased the disused photo-processing booth in Joshua Tree, California, that now houses the self-titled World Famous Crochet Museum. Elf had been collecting crochet items since the early 1990s, years before she decided to purchase the roadside hut that now houses her collection.â 
â 
Among the eclectic collection youâll find just about every conceivable type of item, represented in crochet form. There are animals like poodles, bears, and unicorns. There are also more abstract designs, like smiley faces and lumpy little creations that are less identifiable.â 
â

Congratulations to Tia Margarita (@tiamargarita.sf), one of the newest businesses recommended to the Legacy Business Registry by SF's Historic Preservation Commission.

Located on the corner of Clement and 19th Avenue in the Richmond District, this third-generation, family-owned Mexican restaurant has operated continuously for the past 58 years. It was founded by Virginia and Alex Hobbs with business partners Myrtle and John Holbrook in 1963, replacing a neighborhood bar known as the Bostonian. Virginia and Alexâs children, Penny Moreci and Helen Hobbs, joined the business in 1979, and their grandchild, Jennifer Corwin, came on board in 1997. Jennifer currently owns and operates the restaurant.

From its earliest years, Tia Margarita has been a popular gathering spot serving northern Mexican cuisine and cocktails. The menu was developed by chef Alejandro Espinosa in the 1960s, and continues to feature the same classics that made Tia Margarita an instant success. Highlights include Chili con Queso, Gambas Al Ajillo, Chili Rellenos, and, of course, the fresh lime margaritas. Due to its welcoming atmosphere and neighborhood feel, the restaurant is frequently the site of social, political, and school meetings, and a popular venue for birthdays, anniversaries, and other special occasions.

The restaurant is also defined by its physical features, including a horseshoe shaped bar, neon marquee, Mexican-style stained glass windows, and Aztec masks, which were first displayed at the Golden Gate International Exhibition on Treasure Island (1939-1940). Tia Margarita is committed to maintaining these historic features and remaining an anchor tenant of the Richmond District, where friends and family can gather for years to come.

share.share_text: (Long story ahead) If you know me, you know that my emotions are often just barely below the surface. It doesnât take much sometimes to get me choked up. Iâve gotten emotional talking about a sign or someoneâs response to a sign but Iâve never just stopped at my work desk and had a decent little cry until today. This door is part of a larger piece Iâm making. Thereâs a tiny little lock near the door handle. That tiny little lock has a tiny dab of brass colored paint dead center. Thatâs what made me cry. Getting that paint in the right spot. That little speck. The reason it means so much is that 7-8 years ago my eyes started to fail. Both retinas tore within a month of each other. Both retinas then detached a few months apart later that year requiring emergency procedures to repair them. Multiple laser surgeries in each eye. Iâve had the fluid completely drained from each eye and had each eye filled with nitrogen gas twice (google âvitrectomyâ if you dare). Iâve had scar tissue peeled from my retinas and Iâve had cataract surgery in each eye. As a result the vision in my left eye is scrambled dead center. I canât recognize a face with just my left eye. Itâs that bad. This scrambled vision in my left eye leaves me with double vision and a complete lack of depth perception. I also canât see straight lines in my right eye because my retinas were worked over so much there is residual damage/scar tissue. I am extremely lucky to not be blind right now and thatâs not an exaggeration. I guess the reason I broke down and cried is because Iâve gone from a guy who was just trying to not go completely blind to a guy who can make things like this and who can sometimes get tiny little spots of paint exactly where they belong. Thanks for reading and thanks for all the support. You are all the absolute best. And if you ever start to see flashes or thousands of tiny little black dots floating around, get to the eye Dr ASAP. .#scalemodel #diorama #door #maker #artist

Azor Dutch bike. LARGE. Â£180.

Note: shop is still closed for repairs, but we can arrange a viewing for bike sales. Please ask if  you like any of the bikes posted.

Beautiful Azor traditional Dutch bike. We got this bike given by a neighbour, it was sitting in a garden for very long time (check condition in last picture!). It took us so much time and effort to fix, the seatpost was seized, we had to rebuilt the front wheel, derust and repaint frame.... but it is alive again and ready for a new life. 

Azor bikes are real Dutch machines, made in Holland (yes the real deal!) and known for being so sturdy and reliable. Not as famous as Gazelle or Batavus perhaps (they don't spend big money in marketing), but Dutch bike connoisseurs will know that they are at the top when it comes to quality.

It is a traditional omafiets, with a very elegant geometry, super relaxed cycling position that keeps your back totally straight, and really reliable components. Gears are internal Sachs Torpedo, 3 speed, and brakes are both internal too (drum brake on front, coaster brake rear). This is perfect for the winter (the Dutch know!) as drivetrain and braking performance is not affected by adverse weather, unlike the majority of bikes (that use external setups).

Obviously this an utility bike so really practical: it comes with chainguard, mudguards, bell, kickstand, and rear pannier rack. 

We have repainted it with durable Hammerite anti rust paint, new set of decals and a full service, including new bearings in headset, bottom bracket replaced, new cables, new saddle, and a new set of Schwalbe tyres with puncture protection.
It rides very well, smooth and super comfortable.

Overall, if you are a tall person (over 5 8, 1.75m) and want a stylish, solid, comfortable, low maintenance and practical bike, this could be your ideal wheeled friend.

HORROR NOIR: The Peter Lorre film STRANGER ON THE THIRD FLOOR (1940) is often referenced as one of the first true noirs. The film can be seen as connective tissue: it is heavily influenced by German Expressionism (the dream sequence looks like an abstract theater set, sparse & horizontal) while released at the very beginning of the classic Hollywood noir cycle. When a cafe ownerâs throat is cut, a reporter (John McGuire) becomes both witness & suspect, flagging attention to the odd-looking suspicious neighbor upstairs (Lorre); the reporterâs fiancÃ©e (Margaret Tallichet, aka William Wylerâs wife from 1938-1981) sets to prove his innocence by encountering the mysterious recluse. One of the few films directed by Latvian immigrant Boris Ingster, who mostly worked in television; written by Hungarian immigrant Frank Partos, though contemporary research proves that this was finished by an uncredited Nathanael West. Look out for Elisha Cook Jr. as a cab driver. The film occasionally feels like a 1920s German horror film: disorienting silhouettes, sharp angles, heavy shadows, & low camera POV. The stylized set design & bent cityscapes came from art director Van Nest Polglase (1933âs KING KONG, 1941âs CITIZEN KANE). Shot by usual RKO cinematographer, noir godfather Nicholas Musuraca, with music by Roy Webb (reusing tunes here in 1944âs MURDER, MY SWEET). Influential to noir with its voiceover & cynicism towards authority i.e. molding âone human vs. the systemâ narratives. Shot while Lorre owed RKO two days on his contract which is why he is barely in the film, often seen barreling up stairs into darkness with a white scarf. Lorre is menacing & fantastic here, the perfect representation of horror + noir since he appeared in staple films of each genre (from 1931âs M to 1941âs THE MALTESE FALCON). The film was unfortunately not a box office success. To anyone that has ever had a creepy neighbor, this is for you.

Not sure how to navigate this next length of time and my heart is hurting for so many folks whose struggle will be much much harder than mine. What good are words when the world is upside down? Or maybe we need them more than ever.
If it would offer a momentary breath to get a hand written poem in the mail once a week, Iâve got my weight in envelopes and stamps over here and nothing would make me happier than to send weekly word offerings to your real live mailbox for the next three months.

Hereâs how it works: send your home address to me at stayhomepoems@gmail.com 
Make one donation of your choice, whatever seems right and works for your situation, Iâll let you know how when you email. Anything I donât need for stamps and rice and beans will go right back out to help the music community make it through these shaky times.
With love and gratitude,
Anna

share.share_text:
Built For Battle
â¢
ð¸ by @nealcooperphotography

A defeated warthog makes his escape, having lost his battle with a rival male over the rights to a female.

The "wart" part in the warthog's name comes from the thick growths of skin on their faces, intended to pad them when they fight or "rut" during mating season.

The female hogs also possess these "warts" because they also use their face as a weapon, only their fights are more likely to occur with an attacking predator - and it is usually in defense of their young.

Warthogs can move very quickly, reaching speeds of 34mph (55kph) from a standstill, impressive for an animal that can weigh up to 250lbs (113kg) at their largest.

If their speed fails them, they are armed with razor-sharp ivory tusks, which are basically canine teeth that never stop growing.

They are very proficient at using them in defensive, as well as offensive scenarios.

A woman knocks a black bear off a block wall to save her pets. 

Friends, I really struggled to justify posting this. I do not think promoting this behavior is a good idea because I can totally see it getting someone (or more likely a lot of bears) killed one day. 

I ultimately decided to use the virality of this video in an attempt to innoculate against future occurrences, in the hope that if presented with a choice like this, you'll choose the path that doesn't involve putting your body within striking distance of a momma bear with vulnerable cubs. Ever. 

So first off, let me go ahead and state unequivocally that you should never ever ever approach any wild animal, especially those with offspring, unless all other options have been exhausted.

On the flip side, I also understand the impulse to save your pets. In this case, it worked out the best way possible (for the human at least) but she was soo damn lucky to get out of there in one piece. 

Protective instincts are on full display in this one, and I truly believe that the bear's fixation on the dogs allowed the woman to get close enough to tip the scales in her favor long enough to get the dogs and herself out of harms way.

Just keep in mind that this could have ended very differently, so please don't try this.

Todayâs #portraitoftheday is journalist, author and historian Jan Morris. Her most important literary achievement was the epic Pax Britannica (1973-78), a trilogy about the rise and fall of the British Empire. She first came to public attention in 1953 as James Morris, the reporter who climbed 20,000 feet up Everest and broke the news that a British Expedition had conquered the mountain. In 1972, Morris underwent gender reassignment surgery, having realised from an early age that âI had been born in the wrong body, and should really be a girl'. Taking the name Jan, she wrote Conundrum (1974) describing her experiences.â 
â 
In this portrait by Arturo Di Stefano, Morris played an important part in the painting's development and entered into the process with great gusto. The landscape beyond the studio window includes references to Wales, Venice, Trieste, Manhattan, and Everest, all significant places in Morris's personal history and the inclusion of her Norwegian cat Ibsen, was non-negotiable. Morris described sitting for the portrait as 'life enhancing' and 'one of the happiest experiences of my life'.â 
â

The incredible time-lapse photography of Ralph Crane, published in various issues of LIFE Magazine, 1951-1969. 

Iâm sure youâve seen some of these before. I know that I used to see a few for sale as posters at souvenir shops when I would visit the city as a kid. I just had no idea that they were all taken by the same photographer until I started in on these recent Ralph Crane appreciation posts and now Iâm pretty happy to revisit these as a set. 

Photos: 
1-2: Hollywood from Highland, looking east, 1951.
3. Hollywood from Whitley, looking west, 1951.
4. Mayor Norris Paulson reviews some notes as heâs driven along Hollywood in 1959.
5. Wshire, looking west in 1959. You can see the sign for the Brown Derby on the right, with the Ambassador Hotel sign across the street on the left.
6. The 110 & 6th Street, looking north in 1959.
7. Taken somewhere over the city, guy in a radio station traffic helicopter in the mid 1960s.
8. An ambulance speeds through the city in 1969, looks like itâs maybe through one of the tunnels.

Back in the mid-seventies, probably 1976, my mom and dad and I went on a long RV camping trip with my grandparents and my cousin. I think of this trip with so much fondness. 

I remember Dana getting gum stuck in her hair. About to the scalp. I remember us climbing on a big log that had fallen across a river and having no fear of falling as I walked across it. I remember lakes and rivers and mountains and trees. I remember treacherous mountain roads. I remember campfires and throwing anything I could into the flames. I remember getting in trouble for that. 

I remember the twangings of Dolly Parton and Tammy Wynette and George Jones and Tanya Tucker and Charlie Rich and Glenn Campbell and, and, and...I remember an ashtray in the shape of a Goodyear tire which makes sense because my grandparents were in the trucking biz. It was Shoop Bros at that time...before they bought the place and it became Nick and Dee's Trucking...which last time I checked still exists.

I remember cigarettes. So many cigarettes. I remember the leather cigarette case, always in my grandma's possession. I remember singing "Plop, plop, fizz, fizz" over and over again to make Grandma Dee laugh. And she did every time. She was a great audience and obviously very patient. I remember my mother begging me to give it a rest.

I remember my grandpa driving their new Winnebago with the orange stripes. I remember my grandpa liked to fish with cheese on a hook. I remember my mom finding a giant mushroom as big as my head. I remember fishing with my dad and I remember being good at casting my rod. I remember a bee wouldn't leave me alone. Probably due to the aroma of my grandpa's fishing cheese. I remember throwing that rod down and running away.

I remember sleeping in the cabinet of our RV which became a bed at night and I remember thinking that was the neatest thing there was. I remember laying in the top bed over the driver's seat watching below as we blazed down the roads getting to our next destination.

I miss Grandma Dee and Grandpa Nick. And though the memories have me misty, I think mostly of how lucky I am to have had these times together.

~shared by @tchickphoto #savefamilyphotos

Probably my most unusual and enchanting experiences - to photograph fireflies in Japan. Hotaru ("fireflies" in Japan) season lasts starting from May to around July in different regions of Japan. I've chosen Kyushu island with it's beautiful nature as my destination. 
On these images you can see hime-botaru light dots. These are synchronous fireflies. Genji fireflies are other types of fireflies which leave the long trail as their light dims slowly. 

Fireflies are very sensitive to ecological conditions. Unfortunately, they are not the best in the last few years, so it's starting to be very challenging to find fireflies. Sometimes it's just two or three days when they light up. And you can find this information only among local photographers. 
 I came to each location early, long before 8-9 p.m. when first fireflies start to show up. Found best composition, setup my cameras and started to watch. First just a few fireflies start to blink slowly lifting up from the leaf. 
I felt like a kid looking for the first time in my life at a Christmas tree! It was so exciting and enchanting, like magic. At a certain moment, the fireflies synchronize and start blinking synchronously. Yellow-green flashes light up the forest with dim light, and for a few milliseconds you can see mysterious shrines and the dreamy bamboo forest. It was like a meditation. In deep dark space you are surrounded by soft emerald light for just a few seconds!
I like watching anime and especially I am a big fan of  Hayao Miyazaki. His anime movies are always very kind and philosophical, inspired me for this project. 
I used 2 cameras and 2 bodies. Basically out of one day there are just 2 images in case you have 2 cameras!
I used Nikon Z 7 + 58 mm 1.4 nikkor and Nikon D850 + 24-70 Nikkkor 2.8
It is essential to have wide open aperture lens!
You can't simply leave your camera for exposure more than 5 min. You'll have lots of hot pixels. So each photo consists of 100-120 exposures 20-25 s each merged in one long exposure using StarStax software. Like we do for startrails. Eventually you see this "map" of fireflies. But not a single photo can express that feeling when you see fireflies by your own eyes.

Hi! This is Joel Pulliam (@j_pulliam_photo), and I'm delighted to be taking over. For the next two weeks, I'd like to show you around the city  I call home, Tokyo, and introduce you to some of the Japanese photographers who work the streets.

Let's start with some photos taken by Hiromi Tsuchida (@tsuchidagram) around 1970 in the neighbourhood of Asakusa. Asakusa is a working class neighbourhood known for its major festivals. During the 1970s it was also a major entertainment district. Tsuchida writes: "It was shortly after I started my life in the big city, and I was trying to escape my identity as a country bumpkin, and putting on an expressionless, imperturbable persona. However, I realised that this town had an eye that coldly saw through that."

Takei Moore, who was born in Yokohama and grew up in Tokyo, remembers the communal-style donabe at the center of her familyâs dining table year round, and how it drew everyone toward it for the simmering dish known as a nabe, or hot pot.

â¢ Photos By Asako Narahashi â 
â 
In her seriesÂ "half awake and half asleep in the water" and "ever after", Tokyo-based photographer Asako NarahashiÂ shows the geography of Japan from a dreamy, desolate and disconnected perspective. Floating off the coastline, Narahashi lifts her camera just above the water, and makes a photograph. The images that appear are split, at times almost completely in half, with the lower frame practically submerged, while the peak ofÂ Mt.FujiÂ or another far-off landmark rises just above the glistening ripple of a breaking wave.â 
â 
âWhen I started this project, I wanted to see and depict Japan as an island,â she said, admitting that at first, she didnât have any strong attachment to the places she was photographing from afar. But after the 2011 earthquake, tsunami and ensuing nuclear disaster in Fukushima, people began to see an eerie tension and trepidation in her waterlogged imagery.â 
â 
âThat was really shocking to me, so I stayed away from taking photos in Japan for a while,â she said. âI didnât want to take pictures of the water anymore.â She traveled to the Netherlands instead and made images on dry land that continued her photographic exploration of disconnected landscapes, but did not return to the water until friends encouraged her to visit Nojiri Lake, near Nagano, Japan. âIt was a challenge getting back to this work,â she said, âbut visiting this lake was something of a rehabilitation for me, and allowed me [to find] a way back into photographing in Japan againââ 
â 
Her photographs, which she had called âhappy coincidences,â became reminders of the darker, more ominous side of the natural world, and our helplessness in the face of destruction.â 

At the foot of a mountain in residential Osaka, Japan, is Melt House, a narrow-set home with a central, double-height courtyard that pivots around an indoor garden. âA home that feels green is a home where the residents actively use the external space and grow together with the green,â says architect Satoshi Saito. âTaking a nap under a tree, planting a tree or flowers, and smelling greenery is less common now in urban societies. I thought that I could create an original experience of this rich life that is being forgotten.â Placed at the homeâs center between two wings, the courtyard acts as a multi-functional room thatâs a focal point for light and ventilation. See how Osakaâs Melt House is a return to nature at the link in bio.

share.share_text: In 1970, more than a decade before Marie Kondo was born, the guru Shunryu Suzuki offered some advice: âYou must take everything out of your room and clean it thoroughly,â he wrote. âIf it is necessary, you may bring everything back in again . . . but if they are not necessary, there is no need to keep them.â Kondoâs work is just the most recent manifestation of a long Japanese tradition of cleanlinessâone that can be traced back more than a millenium. At the link in our bio, read about Japanâs earliest incarnations of the ohsoji, the âgreat cleaningâ that is carried out at the end of December in anticipation of the New Year.

A new edition â Bamboo Bear â will be available tomorrow, Thurs Oct 15th and 12pm PST on store.fnnch.com.

Bamboo Bear is a simple idea â a Classic Bear painted on bamboo plywood â but one I have been thinking about for years. My earliest pieces were painted on wood from Home Depot. I started with $12 / sheet Tri-PLY, which was gloriously inexpensive but warped easily, so I quickly switched to $24 / sheet B4 birch with an MDF core. It was affordable, had great color, and the MDF core made it dimensionally stable, but the quality varied tremendously (the "B" of "B4" means the front is second tier and the back fourth tier), and I eventually became frustrated with the many black streaks in the veneer. That's when I decided to tour MacBeath Hardwoods, a specialty lumber yard that stocks dozens of different plywoods, including many of "A" grade. Their wood is expensive, and the staff has little patience for newbies, but the quality is superior. I used $65 / sheet A2 white ash until they discontinued it, and then settled on $78 / sheet A1 hard maple, which I have been using since. 

But on that very first visit I saw the $166 / sheet bamboo. It'sâ¦ cool. Not only is bamboo more sustainable than traditional plywood, but it has a distinctive pattern and texture. I knew I wanted to work with it, but back then I couldn't justify the cost, so I filed away the idea. This year I wanted to remix the Classic Bear in some new and distinctive way, and so I finally decided to work with bamboo plywood. 

Bamboo Bear is 8.5" x 22", spray paint on cut bamboo plywood, signed and numbered from a limited edition of 100, and ready to hang with a picture hanging velcro that won't damage your walls. I am asking $1000 for them. They will ship within 14 days.

When Aztec farmers found blue-black spores overtaking their corn, they didnât worry. They rejoiced. â 
â 
It was huitlacoche, corn infected by the pathogenic fungus Ustilago maydis, which bestows a rich, mushroom-like flavor and makes for an excellent quesadilla filling.â 
â 
While the meaning of huitlacoche is debated, the name derives from the Aztec language, Nahuatl. Most believe it translates best to âsleeping excrescence,â because the fungus grows around the kernels and impedes their growth, thus leaving them to âsleep.â â 
â 
In Mexican cuisine, and an infected cob is worth significantly more than a regular one. The culinary applications are myriad; the smoky, earthy flavor makes a good accompaniment to fat in cheese and meats like chorizo. â 
â

Soft cream is the Japanese answer to soft serve. Creamier and thicker than its American counterpart, it is popular throughout Hokkaido and Japan, and many towns showcase local identity through unique flavors. â 
â 
Touting local specialties has deep roots in Japanese culture. Every town, no matter how small, is famous for something. For some, those famed products will be extracted and swirled into ice cream. â 
â 
Soft cream is also being used for rural revitalization. The concept of meibutsu (famous items and foods) and omiyage culture (travelers being expected to bring home local flavorâoften a single-serving edible novelty), has sparked curiosity around figuring out what's âfamousâ in any given place.â 
â 
Link in bio for the full story on how Japan is combating rural decline with a national network of ice cream.â

The New York-based photographer Denny Renshaw was also attracted to them. Having grown up in Jackson, TN, the birthplace of Rockabilly, he felt a deep urge to capture them on film. But coordinating any type of photo shoot turned out to be impossible: they have no online presence and no formal contact info. So with only vague knowledge of where and when they meet, Renshaw packed his bags and flew to Tokyo. These portraits were captured over 5 weeks in 2013 and 2015, shooting at parks, parties, bars and music venues.

The Roller-zoku grew out of both 50s and 60s rock ân roll but also rockabilly because Japanese record labels at the time didnât differentiate between the two, explains Renshaw. But it was the revival in the lat 70s that brought to life what we know as Japanâs Roller-Zoku. The groups are made up of both young and old, male and female. Their greased up pompadours and theatrical dancing can still be seen in Yoyogi Park on weekends. #dennyrenshaw

When Led Zeppelin arrived in Japan for a 1971 tour less than two months before the release of their fourth album, it was a time of great excitement for the band and for rock ânâ roll in the land of the rising sun. Zep was one of the first big Western groups to visit, and the lads were welcomed with open arms during their five-gig stintâthe more so after their September 27 benefit show for victims at Hiroshima. The cityâs mayor even bestowed on the band an honorary medal, leading the ever introspective Jimmy Page to ponder: âIt made me think long and hard about the concept of war andhorror. 
With its reputation for gracious hosting, a hip and young population, and number of large cities, Japan may be the ideal location for any bandâs foreign tour. And if you were a visiting rock star in the 1970s or 80s, thereâs a good chance your publicist would have scheduled you for a photo shoot with local photographer Koh Hasebe. Hasebe worked for Japanese music publisher Shinko Music and, starting with the Beatles in 1965, he photographed just about every major musician to visit Japan. âIt was just as Western artists began to visit Japan, and I somehow became the go-to guy to document tours,â Hasebe recalled in a 2015 Rolling Stone interview.

Super soon...there will be a #Supermoon! Just before dawn on Jan. 31 a lunar trifecta â the Super Blue Blood Moon â will be visible in the sky. This full moon is the third in a series of âsupermoons,â which is when the full Moon is at or near its closest point to Earth in its orbit. 
It will also be the second full moon of the month, commonly known as a âblue moon.â The super blue moon will pass through Earthâs shadow to give viewers in the right location a total lunar eclipse. While the Moon is in the Earthâs shadow it will take on a reddish tint, known as a âblood moon.â Make sure you get outside to experience this lunar event for yourself! Weather permitting, the West Coast, Alaska and Hawaii will have a spectacular view of totality from start to finish (swipe to see the map). Unfortunately, eclipse viewing will be more challenging in the Eastern time zone. The eclipse begins at 5:51 AM ET, as the Moon is about to set in the western sky, and the sky is getting lighter in the east. 
Credit: NASA

Natalia Mendez has been serving delicious examples of her native stateâs cuisine in this heliotrope-painted room for almost a decade. A rainbow of molesâred, green, black, even white, delicately spiced with chiles and chocolate and cinnamon and pine nutsâare served over tender dark chicken meat, and have gained a legion of fans. And who could forget the tamales? Once you start, you want to try everything. Click the link in our bio to read the full review. Photograph by  @dollyfaibyshev for TNY.
